title: About
text:
üåå Welcome to the Chi-Files!
This blog is a reflection of my journey as a data enthusiast, tech explorer, and creative thinker. I embrace the philosophy that data is the new water‚Äîessential, clean, and something that everyone can consume. üíß


üßë‚Äçüíª Who Am I?
By profession, I am a Data Visualization Specialist, but my role often extends into the realms of data science, analytics, and storytelling. My passion lies in transforming raw data into meaningful insights that drive impactful decisions. I thrive at the intersection of tech and creativity, where I delight in exploring tools like R (with a particular affection for ggplot2), SQL, Databricks, and even tranformating mundane Microsoft PowerPoints into storytelling platforms.
I‚Äôm a curious explorer, balancing my technical skills with the art of data storytelling. Whether it‚Äôs diving into complex datasets or creating visual art with ggplot2, I aim to turn data into a source of inspiration and knowledge.


A Few Fun Facts

üê± I consider myself a non-domesticated ‚Äúcat‚Äù‚Äîindependent, curious, and constantly exploring, while embracing the thrill of discovery.
üåä I love the energy of waves, from the ocean‚Äôs surf to the intrigue of radio waves.
üê∂ Dogs hold a special place in my heart, and my furry companion is always nearby.
üíß I‚Äôm a proud advocate for making data accessible, clean, and essential‚Äîjust like water.
üõ∏ The blog name, ‚ÄúChi-Files,‚Äù hints at my love for mystery, exploration, and a touch of the unknown.



‚úçÔ∏è Why This Blog?
I created this space to share my learnings, experiments, and discoveries in data, visualization, and technology. You‚Äôll find a mix of professional insights, personal reflections, and creative projects‚Äîsometimes with a dash of abstract art or intriguing ggplot2 visuals. üé®üìä
This blog is also a space to inspire others, showcasing how data can be both functional and beautiful, analytical and artistic. üí°


üåä Join the Journey
Feel free to explore, share, and connect. Whether you‚Äôre a fellow data enthusiast, a curious learner, or someone looking for inspiration, I hope you find value in the Chi-Files.
Let‚Äôs ride the waves of data and discovery together! üåä‚ú®

title: Hello World! The First Post!
text:
Every great journey begins with a single step‚Äîor in this case, a single post. Really I‚Äôm just trying to learn how to use Quarto‚Ä¶


The blog name is a nod to my love of mystery, discovery, and exploration. Data can be like an unsolved case‚Äîfull of patterns, stories, and hidden gems waiting to be uncovered.



X-Files





In the Chi-Files, every dataset is a puzzle, and the chi-square statistic is our investigative tool to uncover hidden relationships.
The formula for the chi-square statistic is:
\[
\chi^2 = \sum \frac{(O_i - E_i)^2}{E_i}
\]
Where: - \(O_i\) = Observed frequency - \(E_i\) = Expected frequency - \(\sum\) = The summation symbol, meaning we sum across all categories.



Suppose we‚Äôre investigating sightings of UFOs üëΩ across regions:








Region
Observed Sightings (\(O_i\))
Expected Sightings (\(E_i\))




Area 51
50
40


Roswell
70
60


Pine Gap
30
50



Using the chi-square formula, we calculate:
\[
\chi^2 = \frac{(50 - 40)^2}{40} + \frac{(70 - 60)^2}{60} + \frac{(30 - 50)^2}{50}
\]
This leads to:
\[
\chi^2 = \frac{100}{40} + \frac{100}{60} + \frac{400}{50} = 2.5 + 1.67 + 8 = 12.17
\]
If this value exceeds the critical value, we may conclude there‚Äôs something strange going on in these regions‚Ä¶ but the truth is out there! üõ∏















Important



The chi-square test reveals mysteries hidden in plain data. Use it wisely, and remember: the truth is out there! üõ∏


Visit Quarto

The formula for the chi-square statistic is:
\[

Suppose we‚Äôre investigating sightings of UFOs üëΩ across regions:

Area 51

\chi^2 = \frac{(50 - 40)^2}{40} + \frac{(70 - 60)^2}{60} + \frac{(30 - 50)^2}{50}

title: Creating a Seigaha Motif with ggplot2
text:
The Seigaiha (ÈùíÊµ∑Ê≥¢) motif, literally translated as ‚Äúblue ocean waves‚Äù is a classic Japanese pattern used in textiles, ceramics, kimono and art. It features stylized waves created with concentric circles forming arches. I just learned that it symbolizes surges of good luck - delightful and thought great start to have it for blog post.

Èùí = Blue
Êµ∑ = Ocean
Ê≥¢ = Wave

Using ggplot2 and additional packages like ggforce and cowplot, I was able to recreate this timeless design programmatically.


First need to load up the required libraries. Recently, I discovered package called annotater , which let you add annotation to the packages you use in script! It‚Äôs such a useful tool - future me (and anyone collaborating on my code) will likely thank me for using it.


Code
library(tidyverse) # Easily Install and Load the 'Tidyverse' 
library(ggforce) # Accelerating 'ggplot2'   
library(cowplot) # Streamlined Plot Theme and Plot Annotations for 'ggplot2'  
library(gt) # Easily Create Presentation-Ready Display Tables 

col10 <- str_split("012a4a-013a63-01497c-014f86-2a6f97-2c7da0-468faf-61a5c2-89c2d9-a9d6e5","-")

col10_pal <-str_c("#",col10 |> unlist())





We create a grid of coordinates to serve as the base for our motif. To archieve the characteristic offset of Seigaiha waves, we adjust the x coordinates for odd rows:


Code
df <- expand_grid(x = seq(-16, 16, by = 2), 
                  y = seq(-10, 10, by = 1)) |>
  arrange(y,x) |>
  mutate(y_odd=(y%%2==1)) |>
  mutate(idx=row_number()-1) |>
  mutate(x=if_else(y_odd,x+1,x))





The radii of the circles vary in five steps. It could be smaller or larger. I could‚Äôve also add randomness to it too, but I just kept it constant for now.


Code
r_values <- seq(0.3,1.1,length.out=5)
df_long <- df |> expand_grid(r=r_values)


df_long <- df_long |>
  mutate(r_var=if_else(idx%%5==0,sqrt(r),r))

#range(df_long$x)
#range(df_long$y)

df_long |> head() |> gt()








x
y
y_odd
idx
r
r_var




-16
-10
FALSE
0
0.3
0.5477226


-16
-10
FALSE
0
0.5
0.7071068


-16
-10
FALSE
0
0.7
0.8366600


-16
-10
FALSE
0
0.9
0.9486833


-16
-10
FALSE
0
1.1
1.0488088


-14
-10
FALSE
1
0.3
0.3000000










Using geom_circle from ggforce, we layer circles over the grid. We map the fill colour to the adjusted radius (r_var) for a slight gradeient effect:


Code
df_long |>
  arrange(-y, idx, desc(r)) |>
  ggplot() +
  geom_circle(
    aes(
      x0 = x,
      y0 = y,
      r = r,
      fill = r_var ## just wanted to give bit of variance
    ),
    linewidth = 0.1,
    color = "#fffff3de",
    linetype = 3
  ) +
  coord_fixed(clip = "on",
              xlim = c(-15, 14.5),
              ylim = c(-9, 9)) +
  theme_nothing() +
  scale_fill_gradientn(colors = col10_pal) +
  scale_color_gradientn(colors = col10_pal)












The theme_nothing() from cowplot removes all unnecessary visual elements (axes, labels etc.), leaving only the motif. I‚Äôve adjusted xlim and ylim so that I‚Äôm clipping out the extra circles.
crumbs: Creating a Seigaha Motif with ggplot2
